turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Number 72-5830, Patterson against Warner.
Mr. Higinbotham.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: May it please the Court.
This case arises from State of West Virginia.
It was a three-judge federal court below that held a state statute in the State of West Virginia as being constitutional.

That statute provides that one who seeks to appeal from a hearing and a judgment or a justice of the peace in the State of West Virginia, it required to posts a double bond, a bond twice the amount of the judgment.
We challenge that as unconstitutional denying Equal Protection and Due Process of law.
Before I begin with the merits of the case, I would like to deal with the subject of mootness.
We have made the unusual move perhaps for an appellant whose bringing the case before the Court, of suggesting that our case may be moot.
I would like to point out to the Court that I am not arguing for mootness.

I am fulfilling what I believe is my duty to the Court, and informing the Court of all the issues and all the circumstances of the case, that there was a case in the State of West Virginia that went to the State Supreme Court in West Virginia that was virtually identical, practically it’s not much different.
That case raised same issues as are presented here.
The West Virginia Supreme Court declared the judgment of the justice of the peace in that case void.

Another case, an older case of the West Virginia Supreme Court said that when you have a pecuniary interest of a justice of the peace in his judgment, then the judgment is void ab initio, that was in a criminal context.
The State Supreme Court in this Reece case, this is the name of the case, Reece v. Geis --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That’s since the judgment below?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Since the three-judge court, yes sir.
It’s just very recent, 1972.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What’s the spelling?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Reece, R-E-E-C-E versus Geis, G-E-I-S.
I’ve cited it in my motion or suggestion of mootness, the -- it’ 198 S.E. 2d.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has the statute been --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: 198 S.E. 2d, I am not sure what page it is sir.
It is in the record, I have cited it in the motion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has the statute since been amended?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
There’s been no change in the statute at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, does this suggest that perhaps if three-judge court committed to address the significance of this recent decision, perhaps it would not have reached the conclusion?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
I think the conclusion would be the same.
We have a decision by the West Virginia Supreme Court and by the three-judge court that the double bond has a rational basis.
Getting back to the mootness thing, let me refer to that again.
The effect of that case was, it said that the judgment was but moot.
The judgment was void.
That restored the status quo of the parties.
In other words, that judgment of the JP was void, but it wasn’t the underlying claim that was void.
Therefore, the creditor could go right back in the same JP court, and again sue the same debtor, the same situation applies here and for those reasons I don’t think --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But then, what would happen to the guys, would the JP have to disqualify himself or something?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, as a practical matter now, that’s what they’re supposed to do.
As a practical now even though they haven’t done and the JP waives the collection of appease that may have been perceived otherwise.
[Voice Overlap] Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That’s the infirmity in his judgment, that he was receiving --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That’s the one that the Reece court found wasn't affirmed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is -- that he received a financial benefit if he decided to pay for the plaintiff that was settlement?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes sir, exactly.
$2.50 for execution $0.35 for mailing it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Which he didn’t get if he decided to pay for the defendant?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They said that was why it was void, but practically speaking and I think this is the key to that thing.
The Reece court declared the judgment void below.

Now there’s been no rush by creditors or JP’s or like in the State of West Virginia to suddenly come around and say, “That statute was void, we’re going to return all of the moneys that we have collected through the years.”
Therefore, it’s not a retroactive application.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well the most that could happen here, if I understand you correctly is, this JP collected the $2.50, I get?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: He hasn’t executed yet, Your Honor.

He did not execute it, at that -- we sought to appeal, sought to post the bond and so on, we could not post the bond and that’s what gave rise to this case, went in to federal court and joined it, and so --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Supposing you went into the West Virginia State Court, if the judgment here were affirmed, and sought to enjoin execution on the grounds -- on the JP judgment, on the grounds that that judgment was void, would you prevail under the Reece case, do you think?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: There again it adds the question of retroactivity, and I don’t know what the three-judge court, I mean a West Virginia Court would do.
They would have to decide whether Reece was retroactive, and if they decided Reece was retroactive, that means everybody, all through the years would have to return their moneys.
I would hope to get attorney’s fees if I could get something like that, but I don’t think that’s very likely.

But I think the more important thing is here, is its fact that the creditor couldn’t go back in to the JP court, and considering the cases on mootness, if this Court has decided, if there’s a likelihood of repetition of the conduct that complained them, then the case is not moot, and there’s a good reason to believe that the creditor would do that, because it is cheaper for him to go to a JP court.
He’s gone to the same JP before, and won.
There’s a good reason to believe that he would win again, and he doesn’t have to have an attorney --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you read that capable of repetition and needing review language of Moore against Ogilvy, and cases like that, is being the general doctrine of mootness, or perhaps an exception in election cases?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, I don’t think it’s just election cases.
The general rule that I understand mootness is that there must be a controversy at all stages of the litigation.

In the W.T. Grant case, U.S. versus W.T. Grant that was a case where they had the interlocutory directorship and the director says, they sought an injunction against him and he says, “I’ve dropped my directorship, so there’s no longer an interlocking situation.”
That is only one factor to be considered, that he said that he would drop --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That turned down the availability of an injunction not on mootness, didn’t it, W.T. Grant?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
I think that was a mootness case.
That was a mootness case, yes sir, and he said that the fact that it may just like the judgment here.
It’s void.
He’s not doing what was complained of, but it’s very likely to come up again.
The Act could repeat itself.
Another case that I would rely upon is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Does the court find the statute unconstitutional or not?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Sir, I’m sorry?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did the Supreme Court of West Virginia find this statute unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
It didn’t consider --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, is that the one point that’s involved here?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: They considered the second half of the statute.
The second half of this statute is a double bond also in eviction cases plus one year rent.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But they did know of the statute that we had before as unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
They did not have this part of the statute beforehand.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How can that be moot then?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: I don’t think it is.
I’m not arguing for mootness sir.
I’m just saying that there may be a question of mootness.
It’s not my function to decide whether it’s moot or not, by avoiding the issue.
I submit to you that the case is not moot.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does respondent, the appellee raise this?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
I raise it.
I think that it was -- he did not do it, then I thought that it was my function to do it, so I did raise it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there any problem of the statute of limitations having run if the creditor has to bring them out?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
10 years --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: 10 years?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: -- in West Virginia so he can go right back there and sue them again.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has this note been paid off yet?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
It has not.
What he’s doing is suing on the note, and --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is the action that's been instituted in some court of record under your practice?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I think that’s one of the keys to this case.

There is a concurrent jurisdiction in the JP’s court with a court of record, and I think that gives rise to our Equal Protection argument here, which I would like to turn to now if the Court has no more further questions on mootness.
We have painted a picture of the JP system in West Virginia, words and all, we pointed out a lot of flaws in it.
The Reece case bares us out on one of the flaws that the JP has an interest in the judgment.
We’ve also pointed out that a JP is not an expert in law.
He is not a learned judge.
He’s not required to be an attorney --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But do you rely on that as a matter of due process in this case?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Your Honor, what I am doing is -- what I am suggesting is when you focus upon the double bond, to whether it is constitutional or unconstitutional, to look at the entire system.
We’re saying that the double bond is unconstitutional, because we have very compelling reasons to want to get into a court of record.

When we have raised a question of law, and I think it’s pretty well indicated in the record here, we said that we had a substantive defense under the UCC, and the creditor’s attorney when he answered the complaint in this action said, “We admit it.
This is not a case of obstruction.
You really do have a good question of law.”
I think that’s very significant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is the West Virginia bond requirement provision for an appeal from a court of record?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Single bond and that raises first two classes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Single bond covering what items?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Judgment plus interest, so far that’s the way the statute reads.
There’s no damages for the delay demanded on a single bond.

The statute which covers that is West Virginia Code 58514, which would indicate that in a court of record, only a single bond would be required that would be on the judgment and perhaps on the interest of 6% that can be awarded to the appellant if he ultimately loses.
So what the court of record appellant must post, that he must post a bond like a JP appellant post, he would post a bond in the amount of $318.00 or posing $300.00 judgments in two different systems.
He would post a bond of $318.00, whereas, the JP appellant must post a bond of $600.00.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No provision for costs?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Not in the court of record system.
However, there is a provision for cost in the JP system.
As a matter of fact, that’s one of the things brought out by Reece.

They said it had a rational basis, because the double bond was for the judgment, plus cost, plus interest and as appellee points out and that as is provided in our state statutes you are entitled to damages for delay.
When you add these up mathematically, and this is something I think is very important.
Just the simple mathematics indicates that there is not a rational basis for a double bond.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What are damages for delay if other than interest, Mr. Higinbotham?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: I don’t know, Your Honor that seems to me to be interesting.
Let me point it out to you exactly.

You are entitled to in the JP system the bond under the Reece decision would be to cover the judgment which would be $300.00, 6% interest that adds up to $318.00 total, or no 6% on $300 is 18 more dollars, so you have $318.00.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
And you have court cost to appeal the cost to go from JP court to a court of record is $10.00.
Then you’re entitled on that 10% on the cost, the judgment, the interest of 6%, and the court cost of $10, you are entitled to 10% damages for delay on that.
That adds up to a maximum judgment would ever be rendered against a appellant from a JP system.
If he loses, it’s $360.80.
Now, if you are posting a bond of $600.00, there is $290.00 left that has not been articulated as I don’t know what it’s for.
There is no articulated state standard for why $293.00 --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: From the court, from the record, do I understand you say that the bond would be what, only the $380.00?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That’s all --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Judgment and the interest.
Now, and are you challenging the JP bond [Voice Overlap]?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
We say it denies --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Independently of any other ground, on the ground that that’s a denial of Equal Protection, to require you to do that JP, but not from a court of record.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Which of your points of the seven points presents that question?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: It’s in our Equal Protections argument Your Honor, it is part 3.
Are you referring to the brief itself?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am looking at your brief.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
It’s in part 3 (a).

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am looking at the question presented at five.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Argument is 3 (a) --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Higinbotham, what’s the delay between the judgment in the West Virginia court of record, and judgment in the West Virginia Court of Appeals, or Supreme Court?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, generally I am not an expert on that Your Honor.
I don’t think it would be any longer than a year.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If it were two years, I take it that the court of record would be entitled to require two years interest --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -- rather than one.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: But generally, practically speaking as we pointed out in our brief and the state cases have indicated that generally, your bond from a court of record to go to the highest court in the state, we only have one step appellate system, is only an amount of the judgment, plus the interest of one year.
Yes, sir, that practically speaking is what is done.
There’s not many cases on --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who fixes one year’s interest?
Is that on the statute?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That’s the judge below.
Whoever --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So it’s up to the judge?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: It’s up to the judge to decide what it’s going to be.
But practically speaking, it’s the judgment plus one year’s interest, but here we have two years.
We also suggest that the difference in treatment in the JP system, in the court of record system goes much farther.
And we also argue that the compelling state interest test should be applied here, not just the rational basis test.
We have tried to paint the picture of a non expert deciding questions --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I gather that you prevail on this distinction between bonds -- JP bonds and court of record bonds.
We don’t have to reach anything else, do we?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
But if you decide, we made the same argument to the West Virginia Supreme Court, and they decided it had a rational basis.
You could do the same thing.
So I would prefer to argue my entire case to play it safe.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: What we try to present is that there is a difference in treatment all through the court of record system and the JP system.
We have --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What was the rational basis that the Supreme Court of your state found?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: They didn’t Your Honor, they said that the bond protects the judgment cost and interest, and that’s as far as they went in the Reece case.
That’s the most recent definition of why you required a double bond.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I misunderstood you.
I thought you said that you’d presented this whole argument to the Supreme Court of West Virginia, and that Court found that this has a rational basis?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: It did, but they just said that it has a rational basis, because a double bond protects a judgment, cost, and interest.
Now, where they came mathematically, I don’t see that it does, but that’s what they said.
So that’s the close latest definition of what the bonds function is.
They have defined the function of that double bond.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And in what case did they do that?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Reece versus Geis.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In Reece?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That’s the recent one -- yes, sir and --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Were you a counsel in that case?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I was.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It can amount too much.
Can a commercial bond, what’s the difference in the premium between $318.00 and the $600.00?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: I think twice, $18.00.
I think that is probably very close to what Lindsey, very close to the Lindsey analogy in this case.
In Lindsey, you had a double bond also, so if you had to put up assured, you would probably have not that greater difference, but if you go all the way down the line --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Lindsey involved in double bond that is automatically [Voice Overlap].

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.

Winner take all, we don’t have a winner take all situation here, but if you follow the mathematics of it all the way down the line, you figure out that the state objectives of protecting the interests and 10% damages for delay, and so on, which you wind up with is ultimately, maybe not a winner take all situation, but if the appellant in the JP system loses, he loses $60.00 more than does an appellant in a court of record system.
It’s going to cost him $60.00 more than it will cost a court of record appellant, if he loses, and I don’t see if that’s --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You’re not talking just about bond premiums then.
You’re talking --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Not just premium, sir.
We’re talking about the state’s objectives also deny equal protection law.

As the way they have spelled it out as a result of the Reece case, you’re paying interest twice, you’re paying twice the premium, and that adds up to $60.00 more than the court of record appellant pays.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but in the long run, an unsuccessful appellant to the Supreme Court of West Virginia can be held for costs that aren’t covered by a bond.
I would think if West Virginia procedures like most States.
You know, you can be assessed cost on appeal and be liable for them, even though you may not have put up a bond.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
But we’re posing here an indigent.
We’re posing an indigent, that’s a frame of reference.
We have an indigent who can not post the bond in JP system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On that basis, you make the same argument for a single bond, true?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
Not quite.
This is where our argument comes to as Lindsey recognized, there is this gray area, and there’s going to be some people who are not going to be able to post that bond.
We agree.
We do not ask this Court to overturn Arnold versus Union National.
We’re asking only for a single bond.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me go back to these premium figures that you so glibly throw around.
Where do you get that $60.00?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Alright, let me take it again.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: After all, we don’t know West Virginia premium rates.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Well it was stipulated.
It was found as a matter by the court below that it would be 6% surety.
So, that’s what it would cost on the bond.
Let me go through the mathematics again for you.
In the JP system, we have a judgment of $300.00, interest to be charged on that, that’s under Code 4765 is 6%.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: As fixed by the judge?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: As fixed by the judge?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
This is statutory.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: One year’s interest?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: One year’s interest.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: A little while ago, you said it was fixed by the judge.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That’s in the court of record system.
I’m just talking about the JP system now.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then you can’t know if it’s one year’s interest when you’re talking about a simple double bond that Mr. Justice Blackmun is asking you about.
You’re saying it's one year, but there should be more than a year’s delay, it could be more than a year’s interest.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That’s possible, but that’s not the way the statute was set up.
If you look at the second half of that statute, and I think you are going to have to construe them together.
The second half of the statute is also an appeal statute, double bond to appeal an eviction plus one year’s rent.
That means that when this statute was enacted, this was what was anticipated by the legislature that it would only take one year to appeal a decision of a JP.
It would not take any longer than one year.
In addition to which, we have a two-term rule in the State of West Virginia.
That is, if you appeal from a JP to a court of record, you’ve got to bring that on for hearing within two terms of court.
That’s within one year.
So when you take it in that frame of reference, it’s not going to be any longer than one year.

When you look at the statute itself, the second half of the statute, which refers to one year’s rent in an eviction situation, plus the two-term rule, then it’s very reasonable to assume that the interest will not be more than one year.
I would like to return again to the compelling state interest argument that we have.
We suggest that there’s not equal treatment in the two systems, in the court of record system or in the justice peace system.
You have a bias, which is built into the law.
The Reece case bares us out on that argument.
You do have an admitted JP based with a question of law and he is not an expert in it.
We have in the same situation, a person who has the money can afford to go into a court of record, he can post that bond.
Whereas, an indigent cannot post a bond.
I realize this raises the question of wealth classification, and this Court is not seem fit to go so far as to say compelling state interest standard applies to wealth classification.
But what I’m suggesting is, it’s just not the wealth classification and there is something more here than the wealth classification.
That is the unequal treatment in the two court systems.
When you have concurrent jurisdiction, creditor could have gone into either one of those courts, it’s his choice.
He could go into either court of record system where my client would’ve had a learned judge who is not biased.
He had -- no fees were going to be accrued to him.
Then the compelling state interest state standard applies here.
And it’s -- the burden of course then of the state to show that there is a compelling state interest for the discrimination on the bond.
We also suggest that this is like the Boddie case.
I’m not saying that this is a Boddie case.
We’re not saying that the contract creates a fundamental interest.
What we’re saying is that equal treatment in the court is a fundamental interest, like the fundamental interest found in Boddie.
Boddie stands alone that’s clear from Kras and Ortwein decision.
We’re not saying that the contract equals marriage.
What we’re saying is that the right to be heard and to be treated equally within a court system.
Equal treatment within a court system is a matter of due process of law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there any limitation in West Virginia on whether a lawyer may appear in a justice court?
Do they permit them?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do they permit a pro se appearance ordinarily for trial in the court of record?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: You can appear on your own in the court of record.
One of our arguments, of course is that if you have a lawyer who is trying to argue matters of law before a JP that more than likely he is not going to know what you are talking about?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well that’s the function of a lawyer in the whole system of justice, isn’t it?
To instruct the judges on what the law is?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, if judges usually would have had some training sir.
And that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: England does pretty well with the lay justices of the peace.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
We think as questions of fact that they do just very well here also.
But when you have a situation where you have a sophisticated question of law, then it’s very unlikely that the JP is going to understand, what you’re talking about.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Their question –it's not immediately apparent to me that an ignorant JP automatically benefits the plaintiff rather than the defendant.
Suppose you have a sophisticated question of release or something of that that can be to the advantage of --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
It’s very possible.
It would discriminate against either party.
What we suggest is that, what I would like to see in replacing this is perhaps a single bond, but a method whereby questions of law could be presented to a system of certification.
So that the question of law could be presented to the learned judge, then you wouldn’t have any discrimination at all.
You wouldn’t have any complaints.

You wouldn’t have any complaints about a JP about not being learned, because if you have a sophisticated question in law, then you can present it to the JP in a single bond would not discriminate against anybody.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would you make the same point if the judges of the peace had been member of the bar for six months, and the judge on the trial court had been a judge for 40 years.
Would you say that the JP had to have 40 years experience of judging?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: We’re not asking for the maximum.
We’re not asking for the most learned judge, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I’m trying to get, what kind of justice of peace do you want?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: We’re not even asking for a Justice of the peace who is learned.
That is one alternative.
Like State of Pennsylvania has trained their justices of the peace.
That’s an expensive proposition, but if you have a sophisticated question of law arises, there can be an alternative method.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, who would decide what is a “sophisticated point of law”?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That could be raised by --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Underscored sophisticated.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That could be raised on motion of any in the parties -- or any of the justice --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well can we -- What is the sophisticated?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: I think here -- I think we have a situation right here where it’s a relative sophisticated question of law.
Whether or not --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now you’re relatively sophisticated.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, any question of law that there is a feeling on any party that the JP does not understand it, then if you certify that question, then you would do away.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Who does the certifying, you do?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Either party, either party the plaintiff, or the defendant, or the justice of peace.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Had you ever had a client who didn’t think his case was sophisticated?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Your Honor -- if it is just --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And absolutely important in life and death, have you got any clients who don’t think of that?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Again, Your Honor, there are sanctions.
There could be sanctions for a thing like that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Like what?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: If you’re wasting the court’s time, if you’re wasting a court of reference.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You just want to change the whole system, don’t you?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Do I want to change?
No, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, you enlist to?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
I am not asking for any type of legislation.
What I’m saying is, if you have a single bond.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, how can you do this without legislation?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That of course is the legislature of West Virginia, but if the double bond does not stand, and if the single bond is replaced, it would be very simple.
You’re still going to always have the complaint that JP doesn’t understand what we’re talking about.
That’s the easy way out of that.
It’s just to provide a system of certification so that when a party feels that his question of law is not been properly handled, he can go.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Can we make the State of West Virginia adopt such a law?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
I’m not asking for that.
All we’re saying is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You certainly are, because they do now have a law that says “No” to you.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: I’m suggesting Your Honor, that there are less restrictive alternatives in posting a double bond.
That’s all I’m suggesting.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Your client is a pauper, is he not?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then how can he pay for even a single bond?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Again you’re going to have that gray area.
This is what was recognized in the Lindsey decision.
There are going to be some people who can not post that bond that can not post that single bond.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, how would that even --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: But there are going to --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- help your client at all?
I mean --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, if quite frankly, I think if the double bond is struck down and the only bond left is a single bond, if he can’t post that, and it’s our hope that ultimately that we can persuade the legislature that when you have sophisticated questions of law, there should be a method of certifying questions of law to the court of record.
That would be the simple way out.
I’m not saying that every case that you’re going to have sophisticated questions of law that need -- a JP can find fact just as well as a judge can.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: One of your complaints is this double bond particularly when compared to an appeal from the court of record, which is a single bond plus one year’s interest generally set by the trial judge that you told us.
But if we declare that violation of Equal Protection Clause, your client couldn’t appeal anyway, could he?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Not likely, I don’t know.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you hardly even have a stand to make that complaint if your client couldn’t appeal anyway?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Your Honor, what we’re posing here is the difference in treatment between a court of record appellant and you know, I can’t conjecture to make a hypothesis that he can make double bond and he can’t make a double bond and he can’t make a single bond.
We’re not asking for you to say that bonds -- appeal bonds per se are unconstitutional.
What we’re suggesting is that a double bond is discriminatory.
That’s as far as --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I am just discriminating as your client, because he can’t make any bond, isn’t that right?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: At the time this case rose, he could not make any bond.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If he filed an affidavit, of --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- I think, didn’t he?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Yes, sir.
We’re not asking you to throw out all bonds.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if that’s the only thing it would help your client, the only thing that would enable your client to appeal, wouldn’t it?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, again my suggestion is for state legislature in West Virginia to look for the least restrictive alternative.
Otherwise, we’re still going to have a justice of the peace system with flaws in it.
We’re still going to have a judge who is looking at matters of law.
He is not an expert in them and as long as that continues, there’s still going to be unequal treatment in the West Virginia JP system, yes sir.
But that can be eliminated.
There’s a less restrictive alternative and that’s the method of certification that I’m suggesting.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But that I think you’ve told us is for the West Virginia legislature.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: That’s for the legislature.
I’m not asking this Court to do it.
All I’m asking this Court is to strike down a double bond.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why shouldn’t you have presented this issue to the West Virginia court rather than coming to the federal court?
Once you had a case going in the West Virginia court?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, you can’t appeal it, Your Honor.
The only thing at that point in time --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you could if it were found to be unconstitutional.
I suppose you could appeal it.
If the West Virginia courts have agreed with you that denying an appeal because if there’s a file of bond was unconstitutional, that would’ve ended up being an appeal.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: It’s possible.
We did that in the Reece case.
That was what we did in the Reece case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That’s what I thought --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: But this case was brought before the Reece case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Probably the federal district court, instead of taking your issue up to the state system.

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I quite frankly, can’t answer that.
I didn’t bring -- I didn’t argue the case before the three-judges below.
I didn’t file the action.
I think it was just a matter of tactics.
You do have a right --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If Younger against Harris applies to civil actions, why shouldn’t you have presented your constitution issue inside the state system?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: It’s possible to do it, but again it’s a question of discretion.
When we went in on Reece, we went in to that court on a --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In addition of question of discretion if the principles of Younger against Harris apply to pending civil cases --

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: Let me put it this way Your Honor, maybe I can explain it better.
Reece was in the original jurisdiction of that court.
We couldn’t get up to the appellate system in West Virginia, because the only way we can get up there is on original jurisdiction.
We went out on a prohibition, and asked them to prohibit the enforcement of the state statute.
They don’t have to give us a hearing on that.
In the Reece case, it just so happens that they did, because --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did they object to the jurisdiction of the three-judge court?

turn.speaker: george_r_higinbotham
turn.label: Mr. George R. Higinbotham
turn.text: No, sir.
I don’t believe there was any objection whatsoever.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Gaujot.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
As occurred with counsel for the appellant I must assume that it was quite unusual for the appellee to submit some information to this Court in opposition to his suggestion for mootness.
At the time, it was my opinion that this case before this Honorable Court was not moot, because of Reece versus Geis.

However, upon further research it is my conclusion now that this case is moot based upon Reece versus Geis, and therefore, this Court need not concern itself with the issues now presented before this Court.
If the Court pleases, I would like to --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well you haven’t filed a suggestion of mootness, have you?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I haven’t.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But this is the usual procedure before you argue?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, my original -- I was requested to respond to suggestion of mootness on behalf of a counsel for the appellant, so I would assume now that the motion is before the Court that I could change my position and argue that yes, it is moot.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, a normal procedure is that you file a suggestion of mootness.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I think normal procedure is that the appellee --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When did you change your mind, just now?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: No, Your Honor, within the last quite frankly though, within the last several weeks.

First, I would like to begin with the threshold issue of whether this case is moot, and I would like to refer back to Reece versus Geis, and that the case before this Court now originated in 1969 and Reece versus Geis started I believe in 1972, or possibly 1973, and was decided in June 1973.
In that case, we had basically the same issues.
We had a justice of the peace who had a statutory fee due him, which was $2.50 on each case or each judgment that he executed on.

The court in justice -- in Reece versus Geis ruled that because of this $2.50 fee, it was a pecuniary interest that the JP possessed, and therefore the JP was disqualified from giving a judgment on the case and as a result that judgment that he did give because of this pecuniary interest was void.
Now, we contend now that Reece versus Geis does apply to the instant case, and therefore, Warner -- Justice Warner in this case, his judgment as to Patterson is likewise void.
Now, we get in to the question of retroactivity.
Does Reece in that Patterson started before Reece, does Reece versus Geis apply now to Patterson versus Warner?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if you’re right, can we decide the question of mootness here, or would we have to vacate? In remand of this three-judge district was a three-judge court wasn’t it?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: District Court will let them decide whether there’s question of mootness, because under this being a federal case -- by where it’s moot, but we do is wipe the slate clean all the way down.
That’s the way it’s done.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I’m not -- quite frankly, I’m not sure what this Court can do -- as to decide whether it is moot or rather remand it to the District Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I must say, I have difficulty in light of your retroactivity question that both of you raised.
Knowing how we can determine here if the case is moot.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, if you let me continue Justice Brennan, Justice Cardozo in answer to whether state decisions are retroactive or not, said and that a state may make a choice for itself between the principle of forward operation and the relation backwards.
And I would like to submit that that the West Virginia law is that, and I cite the case of Falconer versus Simmons, it’s not in the brief.
51 West Virginia 172 41 S.E. 193, it’s a 1902 case which says that “It makes every decision of the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals retroactive, except for one particular exception.”
And of course this case does not fall within that exception.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well in the first instance, isn’t it primarily the business of West Virginia courts to decide the retroactivity matter anyway?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And you said they have decided it back in 1902 -- the general preposition.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, so therefore -- so what I’m saying is that Reece versus Geis does apply to Patterson.

Therefore, the judgment of Patterson or Warner against Patterson is likewise void, and therefore, this Court should not concern itself with the question of whether -- in fact there was a proper hearing below in the justice of the peace courts, or whether the appeal bond is constitutional or not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you mean that everybody that’s had a judgment against them with the JP court from 1900 to date is entitled to get his money back?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: As well as I can interpret that case, Your Honor, yes.
That’s the way I interpret it.

If not that, at least this Court, we could assume that there’s limited retroactivity and that the West Virginia court surely follows the common law or the rules as were reflected and set out in United States versus Schooner Peggy and Link Letter versus Walker.

We contend that this case is now moot, and this Court should not have to consider the question of the constitutionality of whether due process was afforded to Mr. Patterson in the justice of the peace court and whether the appeal bond is constitutional.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: There’s nothing to choose, except so far relates to mootness.
All you’re saying is that there is a defense on the merits to this by reason of the Reece case.
Controversy still goes on.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: I don’t understand Justice Douglas, what --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Very well, if you don’t understand, it’s too late.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if it is retroactive so that you can’t let the execution on this judgment.
The controversy still exists that is the --

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, now that’s my next argument in support of mootness.
I suggest to this Court that you use the reasoning behind the abstention doctrine.

This isn’t an abstention doctrine as such, because we’re not asking this Court to abstain and let the state court rule because in fact the state court has already ruled and under the abstention doctrine, this Court even though it has jurisdiction of cases under federal constitution and federal statute, you will not -- you will avoid making a federal constitutional decision on a federal question when you can leave it to the state to determine.
And in this case, the State of West Virginia has determined.
So for the reasoning, under the abstention doctrine, even though this isn’t an abstention doctrine and that we are not asking you to abstain, until the Court has ruled.
What I’m saying is, our court has already ruled.
There’s no reason for this Court to rule.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, really I suppose what you’re saying is that Geis been decided when the three-judge court got this case.
The three-judge court would have determined then and there that the judgment was void.
There was no case in that –

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that’s exactly what I’m saying.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And now you say if we give it to the three-judge court now, they’ll apply Geis.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All the underlying judgment, void and dismiss the suit.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: That’s right Your Honor.
That’s correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: At least that’s what you would propose to them?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I would suggest also that this would be similarly what happened in the Texas Railroad Commission versus Pullman.

And that here, we have Mr. Patterson who has enjoined the enforcement of the judgment of Justice Warner, saying that the judgment denies him rights under the federal law and state law, and that therefore, the justice lacks jurisdiction to make any judgment in the case.

And I would assume that this case is very similar to that, and again reiterate that leaves nothing for this Court to decide as regards to what I’m speaking of only to the questions of due process, whether due process was afforded Mr. Patterson in the justice court or whether the appeal bond is constitutional or not.
Now to his argument as to whether -- I think the Court may be a little confused now as to what appellant is trying to argue.
He is saying this I think basically, I’ll try to simplify some.
He’s saying that Patterson was denied a fair hearing in the justice court because Warner had a pecuniary interest, and therefore, he didn’t have a fair hearing, so it’s no hearing at all.

So as a result, he has an absolute right to an appeal, and we contend and say that -- we contend that there is no absolute right to appeal and we cite Ortwein versus Schwab and that Ortwein versus Schwab, this Court determined that one did not have an absolute right to appeal from administrative hearing for judicial review.
And we say likewise, one does not have an absolute right to appeal from justice court for judicial review.

And we could assume that the appeal bond that one pays to appeal from a justice court is very comparable to the fee of $25.00 that one had to pay to appeal from the administrative hearing in Ortwein to a court there.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, I’m seeing again 25 and 300?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don’t see any difference between $25.00 and $300.00?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: As far as being a fee.
What I’m saying is there’s not an absolute right to an appeal.
That’s what I’m saying.
As in Ortwein, you don’t have an absolute right to appeal from a JP court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I understood his complaint was that it cost him $318.00 or $600.00.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I’m directing my argument to this due process argument now, not to as Equal Protection argument.
Now if this Court should determine that the JP did in fact have a pecuniary interest, and therefore, he should’ve disqualified himself and that he didn’t -- his judgment is void.

And should you further question whether the appeal bond acts as a bar to access to a court of record then I cite the Kras case for the proposition and rule that one does not have an absolute rule to initial judicial determination of one’s claim.
And again, I would compare the appeal bond to that of the $50.00 filing fee that one had to pay in Kras.

Another argument that the appellant uses is that well, here we have Mr. Patterson who is forced into a JP court and supposedly had a hearing, but yet it wasn’t a fair hearing, so it's no hearing, but to appeal, you’re making the man pay a double bond.

Well, if the Court is to believe that argument, then as has been mentioned earlier, any amount, any fee of any amount would stand in the way not only appeal bond, but you’d have to give an absolute right for everyone to appeal, and therefore, it would necessitate the overruling yourselves and Ortwein v. Schwab, and United States v. Kras, and really what you would be doing is extending the rule (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do Mr. Justice Stewart’s questions to Mr. Higinbotham, Mr. Gaujot, suggest any additional ground of mootness to you that perhaps the remedy which he sought if it isn’t going to avail his client anything, perhaps there isn’t any real case or controversy here, because of the pauper status of the petitioner?

In other words, if it doesn’t facilitate this man’s appeal in order to get the double bond provision stricken down and have a single bond substituted for it, is that a real life case and controversy between the JP and Mr. Patterson?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, what we have here, Your Honor, is a situation where one has to post a double bond, but that is to protect the judgment that the plaintiff had received in the justice court.
But if the defendant appeals and wants to stay the execution then that’s where the double bond comes in, as to protect.
For instance, if one wants to appeal from the justice court in West Virginia, you can appeal by only posting a bond equal the amount of the judgment.
It’s only the execution that one is denied --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I’d read it differently.
You say that it’s just we want to supersede that you have the double bond, or stay the execution?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that’s correct.

In other words, if the JP rules against the defendant and the JP court, and if the defendant wants to appeal to a court of record, all he has to post is $300.00 to cover the judgment plus cost, but if he wants to stay, then he has to post double the bond.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What’s the rule of appeal from the court of general jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, there was also a statement made that his Court is concurrent --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The court of general jurisdiction to the Supreme Court of West Virginia, how much is the bond at the previous bond?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: That’s left to the discretion of the court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Gaujot.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And how much is it usually?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: I think there is important -- it’s generally the amount of the judgment.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So then, there is still a difference between the two?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, there’s been some specific question concerning concurrent jurisdiction, and in fact, it’s not concurrent jurisdiction.
For instance, you can not get in the Circuit Court, the first court of record in West Virginia, if you’re seeking anything less than $50.00.
You don’t’ have a right.
You have to go to the justice of the peace court.
Also consider this, here you have -- you can’t consider only $300.00, a justice of the peace can award $15.00.

Now, if he awards $15.00, the double bond isn’t going to be sufficient, because automatically you have got interest, cost, and you’ve got this $10.00 fee that goes to the Circuit Court which has to come out of the $15.00 over the original judgment.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But here we have $300.00.
This case is $300.00, it’s not $15.00, its $300.00 involved to protect $28.00, am I right?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: That is Your Honor, if the higher court does not say that -- if the higher court does have the opportunity -- if damages occurred that higher court can assess for damages that would come out of the additional $300.00.
As well as other cost --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The higher court can assess damages?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or do you mean cost?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Cost, excuse me, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought that the cost was $10.00?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, there’s a whole list of costs Your Honor.
For instance, there’s a $5.00 fee for bringing the action.
There’s $2.00 fee for service.
Of course there’s $1.00 fee for the bond.
You have a $1.50 for summoning and return of the jury.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Which adds up to how much?
Less than $300.00?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, it does.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, you’re not really arguing that the double bond is to protect anybody other than whom?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: The judgment -- the plaintiff who received the judgment --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the plaintiff can’t get that $300.00.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: That’s right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It’s not going to change all.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: That’s right Your Honor.
The --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So the only purpose of the $300.00 is to prevent people from appealing or discourage them?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: No, Your Honor, again --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what is the other reason?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, we must consider also --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That State of West Virginia isn’t making a living on this, I hope.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: If the defendant who posts a $300.00 bond -- I mean a $600.00 bond in this instance.
Should he lose on appeal, if he only loses the $300.00 plus cost, interest, etcetera.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the use of the $300.00 will consider at the time the case is spent.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but so would I.[Laughter Attempt]

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, as I stated before, you can’t I don’t think, concern yourselves strictly with cases that involve $300.00.
As I stated earlier, many times this is a court of limited jurisdiction and many times people come in to this court with $50.00 for instance.
They ask for judgment for $50.00.
In that case, it would be double the amount, and it’s not too hard to believe that cost will amount to $50.00 that’s what I’m trying to say.

Consider also that the justice of the peace is a layman, and possibly the legislature felt that they should try and setting the double bond, would setup a rule of thumb and that the JP, he is a layman, should not have to exercise discretion and decide, well what -- how much will I assess to “A” for his appeal to a court of record, and how much should I assess “B?”
It’s just a rule of thumb.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Assess that $2.50 though, doesn’t it?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could the -- under the West Virginia Constitution, could the legislature bar any appeal in any case if it’s less than $300.00, or $200.00, or $100.00?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Could they bar appeal?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They could not?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What’s the provision of the constitution that requires that an appeal be allowed in every case?

turn.speaker: philip_d_gaujot
turn.label: Mr. Philip D. Gaujot
turn.text: Oh!
Excuse me, what’s in the constitution is that one has the right to appeal, but as set out by law, and of course our legislature decided that the double bond is what is needed.
Now again, I like to -- I wish to reiterate that to appeal the defendant in the justice of the peace court doesn’t have to post a double bond.
All he has to do is post, Justice Marshall.
All he has to do is post a bond that equals the judgment that just covers the judgment.
So what we’re concerned ourselves here now, does he have a right, an absolute right to an execution?
And of course it’s our contention that he does not.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
